dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Ciudad Real airport, built 150 miles south of Porto to handle overflow traffic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Ciudad Real airport, built one hundred fifty miles south of Porto to handle overflow traffic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Originally designed to take excess traffic away from Madrid Barajas airport, the airfield was located a staggering 150 miles North of the city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it was only open for what, like, five years? With just a handful of airlines even operating there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it was only open for what, like, five years? With just a handful of airlines even operating there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The international airport was open for just three years and saw flights from only two airlines—Ryanair and Vueling, with the latter having its flights subsidised by the government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—EasyJet and Ryanair flew out of it, and the Spanish government actually subsidized some of those Ryanair flights.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-EasyJet and Ryanair flew out of it, and the Spanish government actually subsidized some of those Ryanair flights.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The international airport was open for just three years and saw flights from only two airlines—Ryanair and Vueling, with the latter having its flights subsidised by the government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then after the financial crisis hit, demand just evaporated, and the place was left abandoned for years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then after the financial crisis hit, demand just evaporated, and the place was left abandoned for years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Then, the financial crisis hit. Demand waned, for both travel and infrastructure investment, leaving some grandiose construction projects abandoned.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it wasn't cheap to maintain even while empty—they had to paint huge red crosses on the runway so pilots wouldn't mistake it for an active airfield.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it wasn't cheap to maintain even while empty-they had to paint huge red crosses on the runway so pilots wouldn't mistake it for an active airfield.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With the abandoned airport still racking up costs as it fell into disrepair—including having to paint large yellow crosses over the crumbling runway so pilots knew the airfield was abandoned, the airport was finally put up for sale.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Then it went up for sale, and initially they were asking 100 million, but it eventually sold for just 20,000 euros back in 2017.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then it went up for sale, and initially they were asking one hundred million, but it eventually sold for just twenty thousand euros back in twenty seventeen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With an initial price tag of 80 million being shunned, that airport was eventually picked up in July 2015 by Tzaneen International, a group of British and Asian investors, for just 10,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: To a subsidiary of Manchester Airport Group, right? They had these big plans to invest tens of millions and turn it into a hub for American companies entering Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: To a subsidiary of Manchester Airport Group, right? They had these big plans to invest tens of millions and turn it into a hub for American companies entering Europe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm said in a statement that it planned to invest between 60 to 100 million into regenerating the airfield on the basis that several Chinese companies are interested in making it into their main point of entry into Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But that deal fell through too, and it wasn't until 2019 that it finally sold for around 45 million to a local group.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that deal fell through too, and it wasn't until twenty nineteen that it finally sold for around forty five million to a local group.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three years later the airport was eventually sold for 56.2 million to Ciudad Real International Airport SL in September 2018, and the previously abandoned airport received its first flight last month—ironically with no passengers on.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And get this—last month, a fully loaded Boeing 737 actually landed there. After all those years of abandonment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And get this-last month, a fully loaded Boeing seven hundred thirty seven actually landed there. After all those years of abandonment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A 747 landed at the airstrip. The last few years have yet again seen the ghost airport change ownership, with an attempt to rebrand the airfield as Madrid Airport South being halted, likely since Madrid is 150 miles away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Now they're trying to rebrand it as a center for drone manufacturing and flight training, not just passenger flights.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Now they're trying to rebrand it as a center for drone manufacturing and flight training, not just passenger flights.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With owners now looking to rebrand the space into offering tech support, maintenance and flight training, it seems as though it may still be quite some time before we see passenger arrivals at Ciudad Real airport.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the big question is whether passengers will really want to fly into an airport that's so far from Porto, especially with short-haul flights.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the big question is whether passengers will really want to fly into an airport that's so far from Porto, especially with short-haul flights.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, the question remains whether passengers will be willing to transit such a large distance from Madrid, particularly when flying short-haul European flights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And on top of that, Porto might be getting a brand new second airport just 30 miles away, aimed at the low-cost market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And on top of that, Porto might be getting a brand new second airport just thirty miles away, aimed at the low-cost market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, though, there is the increasing prospect of Madrid getting a brand new second airport, just over 20 miles from the city in Casarrubios del Monte.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So would there even be a need for Ciudad Real as a passenger airport in that case?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So would there even be a need for Ciudad Real as a passenger airport in that case?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a tough sell, but who knows—maybe its future lies in those alternative aviation uses instead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a tough sell, but who knows-maybe its future lies in those alternative aviation uses instead.

artist_script:
Listener message: "Hey, just read about that ghost airport in Spain, Ciudad Real, and had to write in. What a wild story!"
HostA: Yeah, Ciudad Real airport, built 150 miles south of Porto to handle overflow traffic.
HostB: Right, and it was only open for what, like, five years? With just a handful of airlines even operating there.
HostA: Exactly—EasyJet and Ryanair flew out of it, and the Spanish government actually subsidized some of those Ryanair flights.
HostB: But then after the financial crisis hit, demand just evaporated, and the place was left abandoned for years.
HostA: And it wasn't cheap to maintain even while empty—they had to paint huge red crosses on the runway so pilots wouldn’t mistake it for an active airfield.
HostB: Then it went up for sale, and initially they were asking 100 million, but it eventually sold for just 20,000 euros back in 2017.
HostA: To a subsidiary of Manchester Airport Group, right? They had these big plans to invest tens of millions and turn it into a hub for American companies entering Europe.
HostB: But that deal fell through too, and it wasn't until 2019 that it finally sold for around 45 million to a local group.
HostA: And get this—last month, a fully loaded Boeing 737 actually landed there. After all those years of abandonment.
HostB: Now they're trying to rebrand it as a center for drone manufacturing and flight training, not just passenger flights.
HostA: But the big question is whether passengers will really want to fly into an airport that's so far from Porto, especially with short-haul flights.
HostB: And on top of that, Porto might be getting a brand new second airport just 30 miles away, aimed at the low-cost market.
HostA: So would there even be a need for Ciudad Real as a passenger airport in that case?
HostB: It's a tough sell, but who knows—maybe its future lies in those alternative aviation uses instead.
